question_details.title: Will a fourth person solve a Rubik's cube in less than 3.44 seconds before March 31, 2025?
question_details.description:
*This question is part of the* [*Bridgewater Forecasting Contest*](https://www.metaculus.com/bridgewater/)*. To be eligible to win prizes in the competition you must register for the tournament. The last day to register is March 24, 2025. Sign up or check your registration status* [*here*](https://www.metaculus.com/bridgewater/)*.*

***

The Rubik's Cube was invented in 1974, released in 1980, and had its first world 'speedcubing' championship [just 8 years later](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Speedcubing#History). The winner achieved a world record of 22.95 seconds. Since then, [17 more people](https://ruwix.com/the-rubiks-cube/history-of-the-world-record-evolution/) have held this record, lowering the time to below 4 seconds. Speedcubers use memorized algorithms to solve the Rubik's Cube and top performances rely on choosing the fastest option and executing it flawlessly.

As of January 17, 2025, three performances are separated by the rest. While 20 people [have achieved](https://www.worldcubeassociation.org/results/rankings/333/single) a time below 4s, only 3 have achieved one below 3.44s:

* Max Park in 2023 (3.13s)
* Ruihang Xu (许瑞航) in 2024 (3.24s)
* Yiheng Wang (王艺衡) in 2024 (3.27s)
question_details.resolution_criteria: This question will resolve as **Yes** if, before March 31, 2025, Eastern Time, the [World Cube Association](https://www.worldcubeassociation.org/results/rankings/333/single) reports that a person besides Max Park, Ruihang Xu, and Yiheng Wang has achieved a single time below 3.44s at solving the 3x3x3 Rubik's Cube at an [official event](https://www.worldcubeassociation.org/competitions).

**Today's NYT Connections Hints (and Answer) for Monday, March 3, 2025**
The New York Times Connections puzzle for Monday, March 3, 2025, has been solved. The puzzle consists of four categories: yellow, green, blue, and purple. The yellow category is 'BE AT LEISURE' with the words CHILL, LOAF, LOUNGE, and REST. The green category is 'FORMATS OF GOLD' with the words BAR, COIN, LEAF, and NUGGET. The blue category is 'CYLINDER OF MATERIAL' with the words BOLT, REEL, ROLL, and SCROLL. The purple category is 'SEEN IN 'THE FLINSTONES'' with the words BONE, CLUB, DINOSAUR, and RUBBLE. **Math Challenge: Can You Solve 32 - 4 ÷ 2 + 1 - 6 ÷ 3 in 8 Seconds?**
A new math challenge has gone viral on social media, requiring users to solve it in record time. The challenge, which appears simple at first glance, becomes more difficult due to the time constraint of 8 seconds. To solve it successfully, one must apply the PEMDAS technique, which stands for Parentheses, Exponents, Multiplication and Division, and Addition and Subtraction. Following this principle, the correct solution is: 32 - 4 ÷ 2 + 1 - 6 ÷ 3 = 29. Those who can arrive at this number in 8 seconds can say they have a great math ability. Besides being entertaining, solving these math problems has several benefits that one may not think of.

**You'll need 20/20 vision to find hidden trophy in baffling brainteaser**
A brainteaser has been released by Betway, challenging people to find a hidden Oscar trophy within 30 seconds. The image is a collage of Oscar-themed props, and only those with perfect 20/20 vision and a quick mind can solve it. Research suggests that games like this can have a positive impact on the central nervous system, improving attention span and concentration levels. If you're struggling, a royal riddle is also available, which can only be solved by a true genius within seven seconds. The riddle reads, 'King Nupe of the kingdom Catan dotes on his two daughters so much that he decides the kingdom would be better off with more girls than boys, and he makes the following decree: All child-bearing couples must continue to bear children until they have a daughter!' and 'But to avoid overpopulation, he makes an additional decree: All child-bearing couples will stop having children once they have a daughter! **Taylor finishes Rubik's Cube nearly as fast as he pitches**
White Sox prospect Grant Taylor showcased his speed and accuracy in a recent competition, solving a Rubik's Cube in 45 seconds. Taylor, who has been working on his pitching skills, believes that the methodical approach to solving the cube is similar to the process of studying hitters and mechanics in pitching. Taylor also mentioned that he and his friend got competitive with solving the cube, trying to beat each other's times. In a separate development, prospect Drew Thorpe is making progress in his recovery from offseason surgery, feeling less sore each week. Thorpe mixed in sliders in his bullpen session, which showed improvement. Meanwhile, prospect Chase Meidroth had a successful day at the plate, walking three times and scoring twice. Shane Smith also pitched well, striking out three over two perfect innings.

**The Enigma of the 50 Monkeys: Can You Solve It in 10 Seconds?**
A mental puzzle, known as the 'enigma of the 50 monkeys', has been shared, which 90% of users failed to solve within 10 seconds. The puzzle reads: 'I have 150 chairs and I feel 50 monkeys, how many chairs are left?' The correct answer is 100 chairs, as the phrase 'I feel 50 monkeys' is a play on words, indicating that the person is sitting 50 monkeys, not that they have 50 monkeys. This puzzle is a great example of how mental challenges can improve critical thinking, creativity, and problem-solving skills, as well as concentration and confidence. According to a study by Smile and Learn, these types of puzzles are ideal for exercising the brain and keeping it sharp.
Original language: es
Publish date: March 02, 2025 12:05 AM
Source:[El Comercio Perú](https://elcomercio.pe/mag/virales/acertijo-mental-el-enigma-de-los-50-monos-que-el-90-fallo-podras-descifrarlo-en-10-segundos-nnda-nnrt-noticia/)

**FIFA Introduces '8 Seconds' Rule: A Historic Change in Football**
The International Football Association Board (IFAB) has approved a new rule that will allow goalkeepers to hold the ball with their hands for a maximum of 8 seconds before a corner kick is awarded to the opposing team. This change, set to take effect on July 1, 2025, is a result of positive test results from recent trials. According to the IFAB, 'if a goalkeeper holds the ball for more than eight seconds (with the referee using a visual five-second countdown), the referee will award a corner kick to the opposing team (instead of the current indirect free kick for more than six seconds)'. Additionally, only team captains will be allowed to approach the referee to discuss decisions, a change from a previous recommendation to a standard rule.
Original language: es
Publish date: March 01, 2025 08:08 PM
Source:[La 100](https://la100.cienradios.com/deportes/en-que-consiste-la-nueva-regla-de-los-8-segundos-que-promete-ser-un-cambio-historico-en-el-futbol/)

**Mouscron Hosts Record-Breaking Rubik's Cube Competition**
The 'Hurlubiks Cube' competition, a speedcubing event, was held at the Marius Staquet cultural center in Mouscron, attracting 180 participants. The objective was to solve the Rubik's Cube as quickly as possible. Félicien, a 13-year-old organizer and competitor, explained that the world record for solving a Rubik's Cube is 3.8 seconds. He also shared his personal record of 9.47 seconds. The competition featured various categories, including the 3x3, 5x5, 7x7, pyramid, and blindfolded categories. Félicien's father, a co-organizer, joked about his own lack of speedcubing skills, saying 'My record is more like 26 meters in the Rubik's Cube throw'.

**Chinese Speedcuber Wang Yichen Sets New World Record in 3x3x3 Rubik's Cube Single Solve**
11-year-old Chinese speedcuber, Wang Yichen, has set a new world record in the 3x3x3 Rubik's Cube single solve, completing it in 3.08 seconds at the XMUM Cube Open 2025 in China. This beats the previous record of 3.13 seconds set by American Max Park in June 2023. Wang Yichen has consistently shown his speedcubing skills, with multiple solves under 4 seconds. The new record has been submitted to the Guinness World Records and a video of the record has been shared on social media. Wang Yichen is also the world record holder for the average of five 3x3x3 solves, with a time of 4.05 seconds at the Zhengzhou Open 2024, as stated by Wang Yichen, 'I am thrilled to have set this new record and I look forward to continuing to improve my skills.'

11-year-old Yiheng Wang has broken the world record for the 3x3 Rubik's Cube, set by Max Park in June 2023, with an incredible time of 3.08 seconds at the XMUM cube open 2025 in Sepang, Selangor, Malaysia on February 16, 2025. Wang has consistently pushed the limits with his sub-4 second solves and currently holds the world record average of 3x3 with 4.05 seconds.

**11-year-old Chinese Boy Breaks World Record for Solving Rubik's Cube**
11-year-old Chinese boy, Ihem Wang, has broken the world record for solving a Rubik's Cube, completing it in 3.08 seconds. This surpasses the previous record held by 21-year-old American, Max Park, who solved the cube in 3.134 seconds in June 2023. Wang had previously set the record at the age of 9 in March 2023, solving the cube in 3.9 seconds. As reported by Wang, 'I'm very happy to have broken the record and I will continue to practice and improve my skills.' 
Original language: ru

Source:[Аргументы и факты](https://aif.ru/sport/11-letniy-kitaec-pobil-rekord-po-skorosti-sborki-kubika-rubika)

**The 50th Anniversary of the Rubik's Cube: A Design Icon Turns Mathematical Toy**
The Rubik's Cube, a design masterpiece turned mathematical toy and pop icon, celebrates its 50th anniversary. Hungarian designer Erno Rubik created the first prototype in 1974, which he later patented as the 'magic cube'. The cube's mechanism allows for rotating blocks to achieve a single color on each face. Initially, Rubik took a month to solve his invention, but the record has since been broken with a time of 3.13 seconds. The cube has been to the stratosphere and the deepest ocean, and has been used in extreme expeditions to explore creativity and learning. With 43 trillion possible variations in each cube, it's no wonder that 450 million have been sold worldwide. The book 'El Cubo de Rubik's' tells the story of the cube's history, including its appearance in popular culture, such as in 'The Simpsons' and 'The Big Bang Theory'. It also includes simple algorithms to solve the cube, as well as tricks to speed up the process. Even celebrities like Justin Bieber and Will Smith have attempted to solve the cube, with times of 90 seconds and under 60 seconds, respectively. On the other hand, David Hasselhoff has admitted to never being able to solve it. As Rubik himself writes in the book's prologue, the cube has been 'practically everywhere', from remote villages to elegant offices.
Original language: es
Publish date: January 31, 2025 08:23 AM
Source:[xeu.mx](https://xeu.mx/tecnociencia/1359252/los-50-anos-del-cubo-de-rubik-obra-de-diseno-convertida-en-juguete-matematico-e-icono-pop)

**The Cultural Phenomenon of Rubik's Cube: From Teaching Tool to Speedcubing Record**
Ernö Rubik's 3D puzzle, the Rubik's Cube, was invented as a teaching tool for his students and patented on January 30, 1975. It became a popular toy. Speedcubers have taken it to the next level, solving the cube in record time, often under 4 seconds, using the 'Fridrich-Methode' which allows them to sort multiple layers at once. The current world record is an impressive 3.13 seconds. According to Prof. Jens Junge, a game researcher and director of the Berlin Institute for Ludology, 'It's a testament to human ingenuity and problem-solving skills.' 
Original language: de
Publish date: January 29, 2025 11:05 PM
Source:[Westdeutscher Rundfunk](https://www1.wdr.de/mediathek/audio/zeitzeichen/audio-das-kultspielzeug-der-er-ernoe-rubiks-zauberwuerfel-102.html)

**Speedcubing: The Old Hobby That May Make You Happier, According to Scientists**
Speedcubing, or solving the Rubik's Cube at a rapid pace, has been a popular activity since the 80s. The current world record holder, Max Park from the US, can solve the cube in just 3.13 seconds. In contrast, the cube's inventor, Ernő Rubik, took around a month to solve it. With over 412,000 participants in speedcubing competitions worldwide, the activity has gained popularity, with global sales of Rubik's Cube products reaching $86.6 million in 2023, a 13.5% increase from 2022. Researchers now praise speedcubing not only as a popular hobby but also as an activity that can have benefits for well-being. According to Polina Beloborodova, associate researcher at the University of Wisconsin-Madison, 'Speedcubing offers a unique combination of cognitive challenge, social connection, and personal achievement that contributes to happiness.' Beloborodova explains that speedcubing satisfies the basic psychological need for competition, a sense of efficacy, and mastery. Julia Christensen, researcher at the Max Planck Institute for Empirical Aesthetics, adds that solving the cube can also evoke happiness by triggering aesthetic emotions such as wonder, beauty, and being moved. 'When a pattern is correct, when a movement is particularly astonishing, these aesthetic emotions can provide transformative experiences,' Christensen says.
Original language: es
Publish date: January 28, 2025 01:52 AM
Source:[noticias24hrs.com.ve](https://www.noticias24hrs.com.ve/speedcubing-el-antiguo-hobby-que-segun-cientificos-puede-hacerte-mas-feliz/)

**Ningbo Student Breaks Chinese Record for Solving Rubik's Cube**
12-year-old Chen Zhen from Ningbo, China broke the Chinese record for solving a 3x3x3 Rubik's Cube with a single hand, achieving an average time of 8.42 seconds at the 2025 WCA West Anshan New Year's Cube Competition. Chen Zhen said, 'Every time I solve the cube, it's a challenge. I'm fascinated by the cube's rapid changes and the endless surprises it brings me.' Chen Zhen has been passionate about cubing since he was 8 years old and has participated in over 10 WCA competitions, as well as the Zhejiang Provincial Junior Cube Championship and the SSL Intelligent Cube Super League. Through these competitions, Chen Zhen has not only improved his cubing skills but also made friends with cubing enthusiasts from all over the country. Chen Zhen's exceptional talent and dedication have earned him a reputation as a 'model student' at his school, where he is known for his agility, focus, and excellent time management skills.
Original language: zh
Publish date: January 20, 2025 03:20 AM
Source:[凤凰网（凤凰新媒体）](https://nb.ifeng.com/c/8gHn9QqLMg4)

**Wheel Of Fortune winning contestant's son SHOCKS Ryan and Vanna**
On the latest episode of Wheel of Fortune, Frank Mentesana of Brooklyn, New York, won $40,000 and brought his grand total to $65,850. His son Braden, who can solve a Rubik's Cube in under 30 seconds, stunned Ryan Seacrest and Vanna White by solving it in approximately 28 seconds just before the show ended. Frank mentioned earlier in the episode that Braden had been working on solving the cube for a few years and had developed his own algorithms. Braden's personal record is 18 seconds, but he has been improving and is now one of the fastest speedcubers in the world. The art of speedcubing has been around since 1982, with the first world record set at 22.95 seconds. The current world record is 3.134 seconds, set by Max Park in June 2023.
Original language: en
Publish date: January 17, 2025 02:54 AM
Source:[Daily Mail Online](https://www.dailymail.co.uk/tv/article-14294801/Wheel-Fortune-winning-contestants-son-SHOCKS-Ryan-Seacrest-Vanna-White-amazing-feat.html)

**Chinese Student Breaks Guinness World Record for Fastest Solve of a Speedcubing Rubik's Cube**
On January 10, 2025, the Guinness World Records officially confirmed that high school student Leng Yi Chen from Chengdu Foreign Languages School International Department broke the record for 'fastest solve of a speedcubing Rubik's Cube' with a time of 1.241 seconds. Leng Yi Chen surpassed the previous record holder Ye Jiahui's time of 2.352 seconds by 1.111 seconds. In the live challenge, Leng Yi Chen only needed four attempts and took around ten minutes to complete. He said, 'I'm satisfied with my performance, although I didn't break the record again.' Leng Yi Chen started practicing speedcubing at the age of 9 and initially focused on 2x2 and 3x3 cubes. However, he later shifted his attention to speedcubing and developed new solving methods, which significantly improved his speed. He has also been promoting speedcubing culture and encouraging others to join the sport.
Original language: zh
Publish date: January 11, 2025 12:14 PM
Source:[中华网科技公司](https://news.china.com/socialgd/10000169/20250111/47857476.html)

**Poligny Speed Cubing: The First International Rubik's Cube Competition in the Jura Region**
The Poligny speed cubing club is organizing the first international Rubik's cube competition in the Jura region on January 18 and 19. The event will bring together 86 competitors from different countries, with the youngest being 9 years old and the oldest 56. The competition will feature various disciplines, including speed cubing with eyes closed. The president of the club, Jean-Baptiste Brelot, explains that the speed cubing is a mental challenge that requires strategy and quick thinking. He notes that the average age of competitors is around 20 years old, with many being students in engineering school. The competition will be a test of speed and skill, with the goal of solving the Rubik's cube in the shortest time possible. The current world record for solving a 3x3 cube is held by Max Park, who solved it in 3.134 seconds in June 2023.
Original language: fr
Publish date: January 11, 2025 08:03 AM
Source:[actu.fr](https://actu.fr/bourgogne-franche-comte/poligny_39434/poligny-speed-cubing-deux-jours-pour-un-tournoi-international-de-rubiks-cube_62089067.html)

**Chengdu Student Breaks Guinness World Record for Fastest Time to Solve Gear Cube**
Cold Yichen, a 10th-grade student from Chengdu Foreign Language School, broke the Guinness World Record for the fastest time to solve a Gear Cube with a time of 1.241 seconds. This record was previously held by Ye Jiahui with a time of 2.352 seconds. Cold Yichen attempted to break the record four times, initially achieving a time of 1.718 seconds, but continued to challenge himself to achieve an even faster time. He eventually succeeded in breaking the record with a time of 1.241 seconds. Cold Yichen has been interested in Rubik's Cubes since he was in the 4th grade and has not only innovated new solving methods but also promoted the culture of Rubik's Cubes, teaching his club members and many young children how to solve Gear Cubes. 'Breaking the world record is just the beginning, I will continue to develop new methods for solving irregular-shaped Rubik's Cubes,' Cold Yichen said, 'I will continue to research and make more people understand and master the methods of solving irregular-shaped Rubik's Cubes.'
Original language: zh
Publish date: January 11, 2025 12:51 AM
Source:[北青网](http://news.ynet.com/2025/01/11/3855414t70.html)

**Rubik's Cube Championship: A Retro-Hobby That Brings Joy**
500 participants from around the world, including some from as far as Mongolia and Canada, gathered in the UK for the British Speedcubing Championship. The event featured 15 events over three days, including blindfolded and one-handed solves. James Alonso, a young participant, won the main event by solving the classic 3x3 Rubik's Cube in just 6.3 seconds, as he said, 'It was a great day.' 
Original language: uk
Publish date: January 02, 2025 03:30 PM
Source:[BBC](https://www.bbc.com/ukrainian/articles/c0kv1eenl83o)

phase_1_result.initial_reasoning: The event in question involves setting a new Rubik's Cube world record in speedcubing. Historically, as of January 2025, only three individuals have solved the Rubik's Cube in under 3.44 seconds. The base rate for an additional person joining this elite group within a short span of time (about 2.5 months from the current date until the deadline) is low. Given that speedcubing records are broken at a decreasing pace as records approach physical and cognitive limits, the base rate for a new individual solving the Rubik's Cube in this exceptional time frame is considered low. Based on historical frequency, considering the rarity and diminishing marginal return in times of improvement, an initial estimate of 10% probability is assigned.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Increased Participation and Specialization
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: The sport of speedcubing has garnered growing global interest, leading to more frequent competitions, more participants, and significant specialization among the top speedcubers. This increases the probability that more individuals are capable of achieving historically exceptional results.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Algorithm Improvement
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Speedcubers continually find and optimize new algorithms, allowing for modest, yet consequential, improvements in solving times. This contributes to the potential for a fourth person to break the 3.44-second barrier.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Physical and Cognitive Limits
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: As times decrease and approach human cognitive and physical limits, achieving even marginal improvements becomes more challenging. This physical boundary impacts the likelihood negatively, given the proximity to the current record.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Competitive Pressure
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Existing top performers continually push each other to achieve better results, fostering a competitive environment that historically catalyzes record-breaking performances.

analysis_updates.points_reinforcing_prior_analysis: The Rubik's Cube competitions continue to gain popularity, and new records are consistently being set. Recently, an 11-year-old, Wang Yichen, set a new world record with a time of 3.08 seconds, indicating that there is significant progression and talent emerging within the cubing community. This reinforces the potential for another individual to solve the cube in under 3.44 seconds.
analysis_updates.points_challenging_prior_analysis: The frequent breaking of records may suggest that the probability of someone else achieving a similar feat in a short period is moderate. However, given the high level of specialization and competition within the cubing community, it is possible that such records may not be broken by new individuals rapidly after such significant breakthroughs.

phase_1_result.initial_reasoning: Historically, speedcubing records have consistently been broken over time due to improvements in techniques, better understanding of algorithms, and enhanced physical dexterity of the participants. Since the introduction of the 3x3x3 Rubik's Cube championships, significant advancements have been made in reducing the solve times. As of January 2025, three individuals have achieved times under 3.44 seconds. Given the historical trend that records are frequently broken as competitors reach higher skill levels and as more people enter the competition, it is reasonable to assign a significant base rate for the likelihood that another individual achieves a sub-3.44 second time before March 31, 2025. summary: After considering recent developments and news articles related to Rubik's Cube speedcubing, experts revised their initial predictions on whether a fourth individual will solve a Rubik's Cube in under 3.44 seconds before March 31, 2025. The revised probabilities from various experts range from 25% to 90%, with most experts adjusting their probabilities upwards following the news of Wang Yichen setting a new world record of 3.08 seconds. This record suggests continuous advancements in speedcubing techniques and an increasing pool of talented competitors. However, some experts remain cautious due to the short timeframe and the high level of challenge required to achieve such a feat. Overall, the revised forecasts indicate a moderate to high likelihood of another individual achieving a sub-3.44 second solve within the specified period.
